questions.text: A 12-year-old male presented with bloating of abdomen and steatorrhea. His HLA DQ2 was positive. Which of the following is the diet modification helping in the improvement of the condition of the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Low gluten diet

 

Option C:

 

Celiac disease is treated by removing gluten from the diet, which is found in wheat, barley, rye, and their derivatives. This prevents the immune response that damages the small intestine.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. A low-fat diet can be recommended for specific conditions such as pancreatitis or gallbladder disease, but celiac disease primarily requires the elimination of gluten from the diet.

 

Option B. While a balanced diet is important, the focus for treating celiac disease is on removing gluten, which is the trigger for the autoimmune response causing the symptoms.

 

Option D. Reducing calorie intake does not have a role in the management of celiac disease unless there are concurrent issues with obesity or metabolic syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most effective dietary modification for a patient with celiac disease, suggested by the symptoms of malabsorption and a positive HLA DQ2, is a gluten-free diet.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th /e p784

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a history of smoking presents with progressive dyspnea and a chronic cough. Pulmonary function tests impaired expiratory flow. Chest imaging shows reveal hyperinflation. Which type of emphysema is most commonly associated with this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Centriacinar

 

Option B:

 

Centriacinar emphysema predominantly affects the central or proximal part of the acinus, sparing the peripheral parts. It is commonly associated with cigarette smoking. It has the maximum prevalence clinically.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Panacinar Emphysema: Panacinar emphysema involves the destruction of the entire respiratory acinus, including the respiratory bronchiole, alveolar ducts, and alveoli. It is often associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

 

Option C. Paraseptal Emphysema: Paraseptal emphysema, also known as distal acinar emphysema, involves the distal parts of the acinus, particularly the alveolar ducts and alveoli near the pleura. It often occurs adjacent to scars or fibrotic tissue, and it is associated with spontaneous pneumothorax.

 

Option D. Segmental Emphysema: Segmental emphysema refers to localized areas of emphysematous changes within a lung segment. It can occur in association with scarring or inflammation. While it is less common than other types of emphysema, it may contribute to localized airflow obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Centriacinar emphysema, is most commonly associated with cigarette smoking and predominantly affects the central parts of the acinus, leading to symptoms like progressive dyspnea and chronic cough in smokers.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 678)

questions.text: The following is the hematoxylin and eosin stained section from the heart of a patient after myocardial infarction. What can you say about the age of the infarction?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6 hours

 

Option C:

 

Presence of a coagulative necrotic pattern along with widened space between dead fibers and wavy fiber appearance sug­gests this to a pattern of injury taking place around 6 hours.

 

The described appearance of coagulative necrosis with widened spaces between dead fibers and a wavy fiber appearance is characteristic of the changes seen approximately 6 hours after an infarction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: At 1–2 days post-infarction, one would expect to see more infiltration by inflammatory cells, particularly neutrophils, and ongoing coagulative necrosis with loss of nuclei and striations, which is not the primary finding described.

 

Option B: By 3 weeks, the necrotic area would likely be undergoing repair, with granulation tissue and new collagen deposition, which is not indicated by the presence of coagulative necrosis and wavy fibers.

 

Option D: At 1 week, one would expect to see the beginnings of granulation tissue formation, which is not consistent with the early necrotic pattern described in the vignette.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A coagulative necrotic pattern with widened spaces between dead fibers and wavy fiber appearance on a histological section of myocardium is suggestive of a myocardial injury that occurred around 6 hours prior.

 

Histological Features of MI by Time Frame:

 

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 548)

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of chronic cough and sputum production presents to the clinic. Pulmonary function tests reveal airway obstruction with a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio. He reports a smoking history of 30 pack-years. Which of the following conditions is most likely contributing to an increased Reid's index in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Chronic bronchitis

 

Reid's index is a measure of the ratio of the thickness of the submucosal glands to the thickness of the bronchial wall. It is used to assess hypertrophy of submucosal glands in bronchi.

 

Option C:

 

Chronic bronchitis: Chronic bronchitis is associated with increased mucus production and inflammation. It can lead to an increased Reid's index due to hypertrophy of submucosal glands.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Bronchiectasis: In bronchiectasis, there is irreversible dilation of the bronchi. Reid's index is typically not a prominent feature in bronchiectasis.

 

Option B: Bronchial asthma: Asthma is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction and inflammation. Reid's index is usually not significantly increased in bronchial asthma.

 

Option D: Emphysema: Emphysema is characterized by the destruction of alveolar walls, leading to airspace enlargement. Reid's index is not a characteristic feature of emphysema.

 

Educational objective:

 

Reid's index is a measure of the ratio of the thickness of the submucosal glands to the thickness of the bronchial wall that is a characteristic of chronic bronchitis.

 

Normal value: < 0.4

 

In chronic bronchitis: > 0.5 due to hypertrophy and hyperplasia of mucous glands

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 681)

questions.text: During autopsy of a patient died due to suspected myocardial infarction, the heart was stained with triphenyl tetrazolium tetra-chloride dye. What will be the color of the viable myocardium?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Brick red 

 

 

Option D:

 

This is the correct answer. Brick red coloration indicates viable myocardium when using TTC staining. Intact, noninfarcted myocardium contains enzymes like lactate dehydrogenase that reduce TTC to formazan, which has a brick-red color.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Blue is not the color associated with TTC staining. TTC is not a blue dye and does not produce a blue color in tissue staining.

 

Option B: White is the color that indicates an infarct on TTC staining because the enzyme activity necessary to convert TTC into a red dye is lost in the infarcted area due to cell death.

 

Option C: Yellow is not a typical result of TTC staining in either viable or non-viable myocardial tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In TTC staining during autopsy, viable myocardium is indicated by a brick-red color, which results from the presence of active dehydrogenase enzymes that reduce the TTC dye.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 546)

choices.text: Multinucleate giant cells in the bronchiolar wall

questions.text: All of the following features are seen in the viral pneumonia except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Predominance of alveolar exudate

 

Option B:

 

Predominance of alveolar exudate: Alveolar exudate is characteristic of bacterial pneumonia, where the alveoli are filled with fluid and inflammatory cells. This feature is less common in viral pneumonia, which tends to involve the interstitium and bronchioles more than the alveoli.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Presence of interstitial inflammation: This is a common feature in viral pneumonia, where the infection leads to inflammation predominantly in the tissue and space around the air sacs of the lungs.

 

Option C. Bronchiolitis: Bronchiolitis, which is inflammation of the small airways or bronchioles, is commonly seen in viral pneumonia.

 

Option D. Multinucleate giant cells in the bronchiolar wall: The presence of multinucleate giant cells is a histopathological feature sometimes seen in viral infections, reflecting the body's response to viral replication within cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The predominance of alveolar exudate is not a feature commonly seen in viral pneumonia; instead, it is a hallmark of bacterial pneumonia. Viral pneumonia typically presents with interstitial inflammation, bronchiolitis, and can have multinucleate giant cells in the bronchiolar wall.

 

Histopathological Features of Viral Pneumonia:

 

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 708)

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient with a history of chronic bloody diarrhea undergoes a colonoscopy. The procedure reveals continuous colonic mucosal inflammation extending proximally from the rectum to the cecum, and notable inflammation of the terminal ileum. Backwash ileitis is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ulcerative colitis

 

Option B:

 

Ulcerative colitis commonly presents with continuous colonic inflammation that may extend proximally in a continuous fashion from the rectum. When it involves the terminal ileum, this is referred to as backwash ileitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Crohn's disease is characterized by patchy, "skip" areas of inflammation, which can involve any part of the GI tract from the mouth to the anus. While ileal involvement is common in Crohn's, the continuous inflammation pattern described does not typically occur.

 

Option C. Colonic carcinoma may lead to secondary inflammation due to obstruction or invasion but does not cause backwash ileitis.

 

Option D. Ileal polyps may be a feature of various polyposis syndromes but are not associated with backwash ileitis, which is specifically related to inflammatory bowel disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Backwash ileitis refers to the extension of inflammatory changes from the colon into the terminal ileum and is associated with ulcerative colitis, not Crohn's disease, colonic carcinoma, or ileal polyps.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 801

questions.text: Which is associated with vasculitis of medium size vessels?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Polyarteritis nodosa

 

Option C:

 

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is associated with vasculitis of medium-sized vessels. It is a systemic necrotizing vasculitis that affects medium-sized arteries, leading to inflammation, damage, and potential organ dysfunction. PAN can involve various organs, including the kidneys, heart, gastrointestinal tract, and nerves, due to the widespread nature of medium-sized artery inflammation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Temporal arteritis, also known as giant cell arteritis, primarily involves large and medium-sized arteries. It commonly affects the temporal arteries.

 

Option B: Wegener's granulomatosis (now known as Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis or GPA) involves small to medium-sized vessels, affecting the respiratory tract (nose, sinuses, and lungs) and sometimes the kidneys.

 

Option D: Henoch-Schönlein purpura typically involves small vessels, such as capillaries and arterioles. It is characterized by immune-mediated inflammation of blood vessels, leading to symptoms like palpable purpura, joint pain, and abdominal pain.

 

Educational objective:

 

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is associated with vasculitis of medium-sized vessels associated with hepatitis B infection. 

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 513)

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient comes to the clinic with concerns of difficulty in using her right arm, especially when performing tasks like combing her hair or reaching for objects on high shelves. She also reports occasional dizziness and headaches. On examination, you notice a significant difference in blood pressure between her arms, with the right arm showing a considerably lower reading. Additionally, the patient's right radial pulse is weak compared to the left. Fundoscopic examination reveals retinal hemorrhages. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Takayasu arteritis

 

Takayasu arteritis is a granulomatous vasculitis of medium- and large-sized arteries particularly affecting the aorta and its main branches. This condition is more common in young women. Its clinical features may include diminished or absent pulses, particularly in the upper extremities. This is due to inflammation and stenosis of the large vessels, leading to reduced blood flow. Ocular involvement, including retinal hemorrhages, can be a manifestation of Takayasu arteritis. The inflammation and narrowing of the vessels can affect blood flow to various organs, including the eyes.

 

Option A:

 

Takayasu arteritis is a characterized princi­pally by ocular disturbances and marked weakening of the pulses in the upper extremities (hence the alternate name, pulseless disease)…Robbins

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Giant cell arteritis typically affects older individuals and involves inflammation of medium to large-sized arteries. It commonly presents with headaches, jaw claudication, and visual disturbances but is less associated with reduced pulses.

 

Option C: Microscopic polyangiitis is a small-vessel vasculitis. It often presents with renal involvement, lung disease, and skin manifestations. It is less likely to cause the characteristic findings of reduced pulses and retinal hemorrhages seen in the scenario.

 

Option D: Temporal arteritis, also known as giant cell arteritis when involving large vessels, is characterized by inflammation of medium to large arteries. While it can affect the upper limb arteries, it is more closely associated with the temporal arteries and often presents with headaches, jaw claudication, and visual disturbances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical features of Takayasu arteritis includes reduced pulses in the upper limbs and retinal hemorrhages.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 385)

choices.text: Polyps develop in early adulthood
Epidermal cysts and osteomas may occur

questions.text: In the clinical evaluation of a patient with a strong family history of colorectal cancer, which of the following characteristics is not consistent with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autosomal recessive inheritance

 

Option A:

 

FAP is an autosomal dominant condition

 

  • Familial polyposis syndrome (FAP) is an autosomal domi­nant disorder.

  • It is caused by mutation in the adeno­matous polyposis coli or APC gene on chromosome 5q21.

  • At least 100 polyps are necessary for a diagnosis of FAP.

  • Since colorectal carci­noma develop in 100% of untreated FAP patients often before age 30, so, prophylactic colectomy is the standard therapy in patients with APC mutations.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Screening for polyps in individuals with FAP or at risk of FAP is typically performed with sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy, as polyps tend to occur throughout the colon.

 

Option C. Polyp development in FAP usually starts in the teenage years or early adulthood and if left untreated, these polyps can lead to colorectal cancer, often before the age of 30.

 

Option D. Associated features of FAP may include various extracolonic manifestations, including epidermal cysts, osteomas, and other benign growths, which are true.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is an autosomal dominant disorder, not an autosomal recessive condition.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 812

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a persistent cough, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss. Chest X-ray reveals an infiltrate in the upper lobe of the right lung. Which of the following is the earliest feature of tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Recruitment of lymphocytes

 

Option B:

 

Recruitment of lymphocytes: The initial immune response to M. tuberculosis includes recruitment of lymphocytes to the site of infection. This is part of the early host defense, which precedes granuloma formation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Caseation: Caseation, a form of necrosis typical of tuberculosis, is a later feature that occurs after the immune system has attempted to contain the infection.

 

Option C: Formation of giant cells (Langhans): Giant cell formation is part of the granuloma response and occurs after lymphocyte recruitment, as part of the body's attempt to wall off and contain the infection.

 

Option D: Granuloma formation: Granuloma formation is a hallmark of the body's defense against tuberculosis but is not the earliest event. It occurs after lymphocytes and macrophages have been recruited to the site of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recruitment of lymphocytes is the earliest feature in the immune response to M. tuberculosis infection. Following infection, lymphocytes are recruited, leading to the activation of macrophages and subsequent granuloma formation.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 378)

questions.text: Most common organs involved in Wegener’s granulo­matosis are:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lung and kidney

 

Explanation:

 

Wegener's granulomatosis, now known as Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA), is characterized by necrotizing granulomatous inflammation affecting the respiratory tract (nose, sinuses, and lungs) and often the kidneys. It is associated with PR3-ANCA positivity, specifically against proteinase 3.

 

Educational objective:

 

Most common organs involved in Wegener’s granulo­matosis are lung and kidney.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 514)

questions.text: A 65-year-old male smoker with a history of hypertension presents with mild abdominal discomfort and is found to have a pulsatile mass on abdominal examination. His blood pressure is well-controlled on antihypertensive medication. Which of the following is the most common cause of abdominal aortic aneurysm?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atherosclerosis

 

Direct quote from Harrison….’atleast 90% of all abdominal aortic aneurysms >4.0 cm are related to atherosclerotic disease and most are present just below the renal arteries’.

 

Option A:

 

The predominant cause of AAA  is atherosclerosis, a condition characterized by the build-up of fatty deposits, cholesterol, and other substances on the walls of arteries. Over time, this leads to the formation of plaques that can weaken and damage the arterial walls.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: While syphilis can cause aortic aneurysms, it is less common in contemporary medicine due to the widespread use of antibiotics. Atherosclerosis is a more prevalent and frequent cause.

 

Option C: Trauma can indeed lead to aortic aneurysms, but it's generally less common than atherosclerosis as a cause. Traumatic aneurysms often result from severe injuries or accidents.

 

Option D: Congenital factors can contribute to the development of aortic aneurysms, but they are less common compared to acquired conditions. Atherosclerosis is still a more prevalent cause in the adult population.

 

Educational objective:

 

The predominant cause of abdominal aortic aneurysm is atherosclerosis.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 509)

questions.text: The following cereals should be avoided in patients with celiac diseases, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Maize (Ref: Robbins 10th /785)

 

Explanation:

 

It is a disease characterized by increased sensitivity to a protein called gliadin present in the grains like wheat; oat, barley and rye resulting in a T-cell me­diated chronic inflammatory reaction in the small intestine and impaired absorption. It is associated with HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In celiac disease, the consumption of grains containing gluten should be avoided. Gluten is a protein found in:

 

  1. Wheat

  2. Barley

  3. Rye

 

Ref: Robbins 10th /785

questions.text: Gray hepatization of lungs is seen on which days:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 5-7

 

Option D:

 

In the stages of bacterial pneumonia:

 

  1. Congestion (Day 1-2): The affected lobe becomes heavy and hyperemic due to increased blood flow. The alveoli are filled with organisms, fibrin, and bacteria.
  2. Red Hepatization (Day 2-4): The lung appears red and firm due to continued congestion. There is an influx of red blood cells (RBCs) and fibrin into the alveoli, leading to a solid, liver-like consistency.
  3. Gray Hepatization (Day 4-7): The red color fades, and the lung becomes gray-brown. This stage is characterized by ongoing inflammation, presence of fibrinopurulent exudate, and persistence of inflammatory cells.
  4. Resolution (beyond day 7): The inflammation gradually subsides, and macrophages clear the debris from the alveoli. The lung returns to normal architecture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gray hepatization of lungs is seen on day 5-7 of bacterial pneumonia.

 

(Ref: Harsh Mohan 6/e p469)

questions.text: Which laboratory test parameter can indicate the highest relative risk for developing atherosclerosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) C- reactive protein

 

Option A:

 

C-reactive protein (CRP) is an inflammatory marker that when elevated, indicates endothelial cell activation and is associated with the development of atherosclerosis and cardiovascular risk.

 

  • C- reactive protein (CRP) is an acute phase reactant that causes endothelial cell activation, promote thrombosis and increases leukocyte adhesiveness in developing atheromas.

  • It is an independent predictor of CV risk.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Anti-proteinase 3 (PR3) is an antibody associated with vasculitis, specifically granulomatosis with polyangiitis, and is not a direct marker for atherosclerosis risk.

 

Option C: Cryoglobulins are immunoglobulins that precipitate in the cold and are associated with cryoglobulinemic vasculitis but are not direct indicators of atherosclerotic risk.

 

Option D: Platelet count can reflect thrombotic risk but is not an independent predictor of atherosclerosis or cardiovascular disease like CRP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CRP is an acute-phase reactant that, when elevated, suggests systemic inflammation and is an independent risk factor for atherosclerosis and subsequent cardiovascular events.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not included as major criteria in Jones criteria?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Elevated ESR

 

The Jones criteria are used for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever. The major criteria include:

 

  1. Pancarditis

  2. Arthritis

  3. Subcutaneous nodules

  4. Sydenham chorea

  5. Erythema marginatum 

 

Option D:

 

Elevated ESR (Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate) is not a major criterion in the Jones criteria. While it can support the diagnosis of rheumatic fever as it indicates inflammation, it is not specific and is considered a minor criterion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Pancarditis is a major criterion in the Jones criteria. It encompasses inflammation of the entire heart, including the endocardium, myocardium, and pericardium.

 

Option B: Arthritis, specifically migratory polyarthritis, is a major criterion of the Jones criteria, typically affecting large joints.

 

Option C: Subcutaneous nodules are also a major criterion in the Jones criteria, though they are less common. They are firm, painless, and found over bones or tendons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Jones criteria for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever include major criteria such as pancarditis, arthritis, subcutaneous nodules, Sydenham chorea, and erythema marginatum. Elevated ESR, while indicative of inflammation, is not a major criterion and is used as a minor or supportive criterion in the diagnosis of rheumatic fever.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 562)

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with high fever for five days, bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis, red cracked lips, a strawberry tongue, and swelling of the hands and feet. The child appears irritable, and his mother mentions a rash that developed over his trunk and extremities. Most dreadful complication of Kawasaki’s disease is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cardiac involvement

 

Kawasaki disease, It is a systemic vasculitis that primarily affects children. The classic features include prolonged fever, mucocutaneous involvement (such as the strawberry tongue and erythematous rash), and cervical lymphadenopathy. If untreated, Kawasaki disease can lead to coronary artery involvement and potentially serious complications.

 

Option C:

 

Cardiac involvement, specifically coronary artery aneurysms, is the most severe complication of Kawasaki disease and can have long-term cardiovascular implications.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: While rash is a common feature of Kawasaki disease, it is not typically associated with the most serious complications.

 

Option B: Lymph node enlargement can be a feature of Kawasaki disease but is not considered the most severe complication.

 

Option D: Thrombocytosis is common in the second week of illness in Kawasaki disease and typically resolves; it is not the most feared complication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When treating Kawasaki disease, close monitoring for cardiac complications, such as coronary artery aneurysms, is critical due to the risk of serious outcomes like myocardial infarction or sudden death.

 

(Robbins 10th 512)

questions.text: In 2 patients with atherosclerosis, one is diabetic and the other is non diabetic. In relation to the non diabetic, the diabetic patient has 100 times risk of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lower limb ischemia

Option C: 

The quote from Robbins indicates that diabetic individuals have a risk of lower limb ischemia approximately 100 times higher than that of the general population. Peripheral arterial disease leading to lower limb ischemia is a well-known complication of diabetes due to advanced vascular disease.

  • Direct quote from Robbins... ‘Gangrene of the lower extrem­ities as a result of advanced vascular disease is about 100 times more common in diabetics than in general population’.
  • The risk of myocardial infarction (MI) is twice in a diabetic as compared to a non diabetic individual.

Explanation:

Option A: Diabetic individuals have approximately twice the risk of myocardial infarction (MI) compared to non-diabetics. While diabetes is a significant risk factor for MI, the relative risk is not as high as 100 times compared to the general population.

Option B: Diabetes is a major risk factor for stroke, but the relative risk of stroke in diabetic individuals compared to non-diabetics is not typically cited as 100 times higher. The risk may be elevated, but not to the extent described.

Option D: While diabetes is associated with an increased risk of cerebrovascular disease, including vertebrobasilar insufficiency, the relative risk compared to non-diabetics is not typically stated as 100 times higher.

Educational objective:

Gangrene of the lower extrem­ities as a result of advanced vascular disease is about 100 times more common in diabetics than in general population.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 1145)

questions.text: Most friable vegetation is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Infective endocarditis

 

Option A:

 

 

Educational objective:

 

The most friable vegetations, which are indicative of a high risk of embolization, are seen in infective endocarditis.

 

Friability refers to how easily a lesion breaks apart or embolizes. In cardiac vegetations, infective endocarditis (IE) is known to produce the most friable vegetations, due to their soft, necrotic, and loosely attached nature.

 

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 563)

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with severe hypertension and worsening renal function is evaluated for suspected systemic vasculitis. She has a history of intermittent claudication and abdominal pain following meals. A biopsy of a medium-sized artery in her leg shows transmural inflammation with fibrinoid necrosis. Based on her clinical presentation, Polyarteritis nodosa does not involve:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pulmonary artery

 

Option A:

 

Polyarteritis nodosa typically does not involve the pulmonary arteries. It tends to affect arteries supplying various organs and tissues, but the pulmonary arteries are not commonly affected. 

 

Although large and muscular, pulmonary arteries are part of the pulmonary circulation, which is a low-pressure system distinct from the systemic arteries.

 

PAN is strictly a systemic vasculitis, the pulmonary arteries are consistently uninvolved. Therefore, option (a) is correct.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Polyarteritis nodosa can involve bronchial arteries. In fact, it can affect arteries throughout the body, including those supplying the respiratory system.

 

Option C: Polyarteritis nodosa commonly involves the renal arteries. Renal artery involvement can lead to renal ischemia and glomerulonephritis, which are characteristic features of PAN.

 

Option D: Polyarteritis nodosa typically does not commonly involve cerebral arteries. However, the best answer in the given question is pulmonary artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In polyarteritis nodosa, the pulmonary arteries are typically spared, which helps differentiate it from other systemic vasculitides that can involve the lungs.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th / 513)

choices.text: Due to toxin secretion by streptococci

questions.text: A patient presents with signs and symptoms suggestive of acute rheumatic fever following a streptococcal pharyngitis. Which underlying mechanism is implicated in the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cross reactivity with exogenous antigen

Option A:

Cross-reactivity with exogenous antigen explains the mechanism whereby antibodies directed against the M proteins of streptococci cross-react with self-antigens in the heart and other tissues.

  • Acute rheumatic fever results from immune response to group A streptococci (Strep. pyogenes) which cross-reacts with host tissues.
  • The antibodies directed against the M proteins of streptococci cross react with the self antigens in the heart.
  • In addition, CD4+ T cells specific for streptococcal peptides also react with self proteins in the heart and produce macrophage activating cytokines. So, the damage to the heart tissue is a combination of antibody and T-cell mediated reactions.

Explanation:

Option B: The innocent bystander effect is a mechanism where tissue damage occurs as a result of immune response against an infectious agent but is not the primary pathogenic mechanism in acute rheumatic fever.

Option C: While streptococci do secrete toxins, these are not the primary cause of the pathology seen in acute rheumatic fever, which is more related to the immune response than the direct effect of toxins.

Option D: Pyrogenic cytokines contribute to the symptoms of inflammation and fever, but the release of such cytokines is not the initial trigger for the development of acute rheumatic fever.

Educational Objective:

Acute rheumatic fever is an autoimmune condition triggered by the immune response to group A streptococcal infection, which cross-reacts with host tissues leading to heart, joint, skin, and brain tissue damage.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 562)

questions.text: An elderly male who had suffered Parkinson's disease for 15 years, developed fever, cough with yellow "phlegm" and breathlessness for 3 days. These symptoms were associated with a sharp, stabbing pain over her left lower chest that was worse when he took a deep breath. He was admitted to hospital with signs of septicaemia - high fever, increased heart rate (130/min) and decreased blood pressure (80/50). There was decreased air entry and a pleural rub over her left lower chest. She died on the same day. The presence of alveoli filled with exudates with the air being displaced converting the lung into a solid organ suggests which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Lobar pneumonia

 

Option D:

 

Explanation:

Option A: Chronic bronchitis: Chronic bronchitis is characterized by inflammation of the bronchi, leading to chronic cough and excessive mucus production. It does not typically result in the solidification of lung tissue.

Option B: Bronchial asthma: Asthma is characterized by reversible airway obstruction due to bronchospasm and inflammation. It does not cause the solidification of lung tissue seen in lobar pneumonia.

Option C: Bronchiectasis: Bronchiectasis involves the dilation and destruction of bronchi, leading to chronic cough and recurrent infections. While it can cause lung damage, it doesn't result in the same pattern of solidification as seen in lobar pneumonia

Educational Objective:

The presence of alveoli filled with exudates with the air being displaced converting the lung into a solid organ suggests lobar pneumonia.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 708)

questions.text: A medical resident is reviewing the pathology of tuberculosis (TB) with their attending. They are trying to differentiate the features of primary TB from secondary (reactivation) TB. Which of the following is least likely to be found in primary tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cavitation

 

Option A:

 

Cavitation: Cavitation is more characteristic of secondary TB, occurring when previously sensitized host defenses mobilize to contain a reactivated infection, resulting in caseous necrosis and cavity formation in the lungs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Caseation: Caseation, which is a form of necrosis associated with TB, can occur in both primary and secondary tuberculosis as part of the granuloma formation process.

 

Option C: Calcification: Calcification in primary TB is part of the Ghon complex, representing healing and containment of the infection, often seen in primary TB lesions.

 

Option D: Langhans giant cell: Langhans giant cells are a type of multinucleated giant cell seen in granulomas and can be found in both primary and secondary TB as part of the body's immune response to the infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cavitation is more frequently associated with secondary tuberculosis, where a previously sensitized host's immune response leads to caseous necrosis and cavity formation. This feature is less commonly observed in primary tuberculosis.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 375)

questions.text: In patients with a history of intravenous drug use, which heart valve is most commonly affected by infective endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tricuspid valve

 

Option D:

 

The most common heart valve involved in intravenous (IV) drug users is the tricuspid valve. Intravenous drug use can introduce bacteria into the bloodstream, leading to infections on heart valves. The tricuspid valve is particularly susceptible due to the direct flow of blood from the venous system into the right atrium and then the right ventricle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intravenous drug use predisposes individuals to infective endocarditis predominantly involving the tricuspid valve due to the direct flow of potentially infected blood from venous circulation to the right side of the heart.

 

Common Sites of Involvement in IE:

 

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 563)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a three-day history of productive cough, fever, and pleuritic chest pain. Chest X-ray reveals lobar consolidation in the right lower lobe. On histopathological examination, the affected lung tissue shows grey hepatisation. Which of the following is a finding of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Accumulation of fibrin

 

Option D:

 

Accumulation of fibrin: During the grey hepatisation stage of pneumonia, there is a persistent fibrinopurulent exudate with the breakdown of red blood cells, leading to a greyish appearance of lung tissue due to an ongoing inflammatory response.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: WBCs fill the alveoli: While white blood cells are present in the alveoli during pneumonia, the term "grey hepatisation" does not specifically refer to this feature.

 

Option B: RBCs fill the alveoli: Red blood cells contribute to the earlier stage known as red hepatisation, not the grey hepatisation stage of pneumonia.

 

Option C: Organisms fill the alveoli: While infectious organisms cause the pneumonia, the term "grey hepatisation" refers to the stage characterized by the breakdown of red blood cells and inflammatory cells, rather than the presence of organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Grey hepatisation in pneumonia is characterized by the accumulation of fibrin and breakdown of red blood cells, with a predominance of leukocytes, corresponding with a more advanced stage of lung tissue consolidation.

 

Stages of Lobar Pneumonia:

 

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 706)

questions.text: ANCA is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgA Vasculitis 

 

Option B: 

 

IgA Vasculitis is not typically associated with ANCA. It is an immune-mediated vasculitis that primarily affects small vessels and is often characterized by palpable purpura, abdominal pain, joint pain, and kidney involvement.

 

Antineutrophil Cytoplasmic Antibodies (ANCA) are autoantibodies that target components of neutrophils' cytoplasmic granules. ANCA-associated vasculitides (AAV) are a group of autoimmune diseases characterized by inflammation of small blood vessels. Among the options provided:

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA): Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis is associated with PR 3ANCA (directed against proteinase 3), 

 

Option C. Microscopic polyangiitis: Microscopic polyangiitis is associated with MPO ANCA, directed against myeloperoxidase (MPO).

 

Option D. Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (EGPA):  Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis is associated with MPO ANCA directed against myeloperoxidase (MPO).

 

Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are not seen with IgA Vasculitis.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 512)

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient, previously treated for pulmonary tuberculosis, presents with cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss. He has been diagnosed with reactivation of tuberculosis. This lesion is most likely to be located near:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Apex

 

Option A:

 

 Reactivated tuberculosis (TB) typically occurs in areas of the lung where the oxygen tension is higher. Let's analyze each option:

 

Apex: This is a common site for reactivated TB. The apex of the lung has a relatively higher oxygen perfusion ratio.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Near bronchus: TB can occur near bronchi, but reactivation often happens in areas with higher oxygen tension.

 

Option C. Subpleurally: TB can occur subpleurally, but reactivation is more common in areas with higher oxygen tension.

 

Option D. Base: The base of the lung has lower oxygen perfusion ratio, making it less favorable for reactivated TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reactivated tuberculosis (TB) typically occurs in apex of lung.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 370)

questions.text: A 17-year-old presented with intussusception and was found to be having a polyp. A biopsy is taken and is shown alongside. What is the likely diagnosis in this individual?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Peutz Jegher polyp

 

Option D:

 

The Peutz-Jegher polyp is part of an autosomal dominant syndrome characterized by hamartomatous polyps throughout the gastrointestinal tract. The biopsy showing an arborizing pattern aligns with the diagnosis of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, fitting with the patient's clinical presentation

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Juvenile polyps do not typically cause intussusception in older children or teenagers and are not characterized by an arborizing architecture on histology.

 

Option B. Adenomatous polyps are neoplastic and could be associated with intussusception; however, they do not show the arborizing histological pattern seen in the provided biopsy.

 

Option C. Tubulovillous adenomas are not typically associated with the genetic syndrome in question and do not have the arborizing architecture shown in the biopsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The histological pattern of the polyp and the clinical presentation of intussusception at a young age suggest a diagnosis of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. This condition is associated with hamartomatous polyps that have a tree-like architectural pattern and increased cancer risk.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 809-810

questions.text: In Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, polyps are mainly seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Jejunum

 

Option D:

 

The polyps of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) are most com­mon in the small intestine especially jejunum, although they may occur in the stomach and colon, and, with much lower frequency, in the bladder and lungs.

 

The jejunum is the most frequently affected site, and patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome often develop polyps here that can cause complications like intussusception.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rectal involvement is possible in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, but it is not the primary site of polyp development.

 

Option B. The colon can be involved, but the small intestine, particularly the jejunum, is the most common site for polyps in this syndrome.

 

Option C. Esophageal polyps are quite uncommon in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, with the condition typically affecting the small intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Jejunum is the most common site for the characteristic hamartomatous polyps of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

 

Location of Polyps in PJS:

 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 809

choices.text: Remnant of proximal part of vitellointestinal duct
Present in 3% of the population

questions.text: What is false about Meckel’s diverticulitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Present in 3% of the population

 

Option C:

 

Meckel diverticulum occurs as a result of failed involu­tion of the vitelline duct, which connects the lumen of the developing gut to the yolk sac. This solitary divertic­ulum extends from the antimesenteric side of the bowel.

 

The “rule of 2s” is often used to help remember charac­teristics of Meckel diverticula, which:

 

The prevalence of Meckel's diverticulum in the general population is 2%, not 3%, making this statement false.

 

  • Affects 2% of the population

  • Are generally present within 2 feet (60 cm) of the ileocecal valve

  • Are approximately 2 inches (5 cm) long

  • Are twice as common in males

  • Are most often symptomatic by age 2 (only approximately 4% are ever symptomatic).

  • Has 2 types of mucosa: gastric and pancreatic mucosa.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The proximal part of the vitellointestinal duct is the correct embryological origin of Meckel's diverticulum.

 

Option B. Symptoms of Meckel's diverticulitis may include periumbilical pain, which sometimes leads to a clinical picture resembling that of acute appendicitis.

 

Option D. Meckel's diverticulum is indeed located on the anti-mesenteric border of the ileum, which is the edge of the intestine that is not attached to the mesentery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meckel's diverticulum is present in 2% of the population, not 3%.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 755

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a month-long history of malaise, weight loss, and renal impairment. His urinalysis shows microscopic hematuria and proteinuria. A chest X-ray reveals bilateral nodular infiltrates. Serology tests are positive for p-ANCA. Small vessels vasculitis is seen in
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Microscopic polyangiitis

 

Option D:

 

Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) is a type of small-vessel vasculitis. It is characterized by inflammation of small blood vessels, including capillaries, venules, and arterioles. MPA is often associated with the presence of antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) and primarily affects the kidneys and lungs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Giant Cell Arteritis: Giant cell arteritis is primarily a large- and medium-sized vessel vasculitis. It typically involves large arteries such as the temporal arteries.

 

Option B: Takayasu Arteritis: Takayasu arteritis is a large-vessel vasculitis that affects the aorta and its major branches. It usually involves the large vessels rather than the small vessels.

 

Option C: Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN): Polyarteritis nodosa is a medium-sized vessel vasculitis that affects multiple organs. It is not typically considered a small-vessel vasculitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

This condition is a small-vessel vasculitis commonly associated with p-ANCA, involving the kidneys and lungs, which aligns with the patient's presentation of renal impairment, pulmonary nodules, and positive serology.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 513)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with acute myocardial infarction passed away two days post-admission. Autopsy revealed transmural coagulative necrosis in the myocardium. Which microscopic feature would most likely be present at this stage of myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neutrophilic infiltration surrounding coagula­tive necrosis

 

In the early stages of myocardial infarction, coagulative necrosis is typically accompanied by neutrophilic infiltration, indicating the acute inflammatory response to tissue injury. This response occurs before the later stages of healing with features like fibroblasts and collagen deposition.

 

Option C:

 

Neutrophilic infiltration surrounding coagulative necrosis is characteristic of the acute inflammatory response seen in the initial phase of myocardial infarction, which would correspond to the timeline given in the scenario.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Fibroblasts and collagen are typically present during the healing and scar formation phase of myocardial infarction, which generally occurs several days to weeks after the initial event.

 

Option B: Granulation tissue is part of the proliferative phase of healing, usually seen about a week after an MI, not within the first few days.

 

Option D: Granulomatous inflammation is not a feature of myocardial infarction; it is associated with chronic inflammation due to specific diseases such as tuberculosis or sarcoidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the early stages of myocardial infarction, typically within the first 3 days, neutrophils are the first inflammatory cells to respond to the necrotic tissue, reflecting an acute inflammatory response.

 

Timeline of histological changes after myocardial infarction:

 

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 547)

choices.text: Commonest site is ascending colon and cecum

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents with a two-week history of bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. Colonoscopy reveals several ulcers in the cecum and ascending colon.  The patient has a travel history to an area with poor sanitation. All are true about amoebic ulcer except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perforation is common

 

Option C:

 

Contrary to this statement, perforation is not a common complication of amoebic ulcers; it is relatively rare and suggests other underlying or superimposed pathologies if present.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The cecum and ascending colon are indeed the most common sites for amoebic ulcers, matching the patient's colonoscopic findings.

 

Option B. Flask-shaped ulcers are indicative of amoebic colitis, where the invading Entamoeba histolytica causes deep ulcers with undermined edges.

 

Option D. The histology of amoebic colitis typically shows minimal inflammation, as the trophozoites of Entamoeba histolytica cause cell lysis and necrosis without inducing a significant inflammatory response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amoebic ulcers are typically seen in the colon, particularly in the cecum and ascending colon. They are associated with amoebic colitis caused by the protozoan parasite Entamoeba histolytica. These ulcers are usually deep with undermined edges, giving them the flask-shaped appearance. Perforation is not a common feature of amoebic ulcers

 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 796

questions.text: Ferruginous bodies are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Asbestosis

 

 

Option C:

 

Asbestosis: Asbestosis is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibers. Ferruginous bodies are specifically associated with asbestos exposure. These bodies are formed when iron-containing proteins coat asbestos fibers in the lungs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Silicosis: Silicosis is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of crystalline silica dust.

 

Option B: Byssinosis: Byssinosis, also known as "brown lung disease" or "Monday fever," is an occupational lung disease caused by the inhalation of cotton, flax, or hemp dust.

 

Option D: Bagassosis: Bagassosis is a type of pneumoconiosis caused by the inhalation of dust from moldy sugarcane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ferruginous bodies are not typically associated with silicosis, byssinosis and bagassosis.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 701)

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with a history of bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. A colonoscopy reveals ulcerations. Biopsies are taken, and the patient is diagnosed with amoebic colitis caused by Entamoeba histolytica. The most common site for amoebiasis:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cecum

 

Option C:

 

Amoebic ulcers are typically seen in the colon, particularly in the cecum and ascending colon. They are associated with amoebic colitis caused by the protozoan parasite Entamoeba histolytica. These ulcers are usually deep with undermined edges, giving them the flask-shaped appearance.

 

The cecum, followed by the ascending colon, is the most frequent location for amoebic ulcers within the colon due to factors such as stasis and bacterial content, providing a conducive environment for Entamoeba histolytica.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The sigmoid colon can be affected by amoebic colitis, but it is not the most common site of amoebic involvement in the colon.

 

Option B. Amoebiasis may involve the transverse colon, but such involvement is less common than in the cecum and ascending colon.

 

Option D. The liver is indeed the most common extraintestinal site affected by amoebiasis, often resulting from hematogenous spread from the intestinal lesion, but within the intestine itself, the cecum is the most commonly affected site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cecum is the most common site for amoebiasis within the intestine, presenting typically with deep ulcers that have undermined edges, often giving a flask-shaped appearance.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th /795

questions.text: A 5‑year‑old child presents with perivascular IgA deposition and neutrophilic collection. There is erythematous rash on the lower limbs and non-blanching purpura. The likely diagnosis in the child is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Henoch-Schonlein Purpura

 

Option A:

 

HSP is a small-vessel vasculitis that commonly occurs in children. It is characterized by perivascular IgA deposition, neutrophilic infiltration, and involvement of small blood vessels. Skin manifestations often include a rash on the lower limbs, which may be erythematous and have non-blanching purpura.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Wegener's Granulomatosis: Wegener's granulomatosis is a form of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), which primarily affects the upper and lower respiratory tracts and kidneys. It is not typically associated with IgA deposition.

 

Option C: Giant Cell Vasculitis: Giant cell vasculitis, such as giant cell arteritis, usually occurs in older individuals and involves large and medium-sized arteries. It is not commonly seen in children and does not present with the characteristic skin findings described.

 

Option D: Kawasaki's Disease: Kawasaki's disease is a vasculitis that affects medium-sized vessels, particularly the coronary arteries. While it can present with a rash, it is not associated with perivascular IgA deposition, which is a characteristic feature of HSP.

 

Educational objective:

 

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a small-vessel vasculitis that most commonly occurs in children and is characterized by a tetrad of palpable purpura, abdominal pain, arthralgia, and renal involvement. It is often preceded by an upper respiratory tract infection and is associated with IgA immune complex deposition in the affected vessels.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 561)

questions.text: All of the following are seen in asbestosis except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Diffuse alveolar damage

 

Option A:

 

Diffuse alveolar damage: is not a typical finding in asbestosis. Asbestosis is characterized by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis rather than diffuse alveolar damage. Diffuse alveolar damage is more commonly associated with conditions such as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Calcified pleural plaques: This is a characteristic feature of asbestosis. Asbestos exposure can lead to the formation of pleural plaques, which are areas of fibrous thickening and calcification on the pleura. These plaques are a hallmark of asbestos-related lung disease.

 

Option C: Diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis: This is a correct option. Asbestosis is primarily characterized by the deposition of asbestos fibers in the lungs, leading to pulmonary fibrosis. It involves the interstitium of the lungs, causing scarring and impairment of lung function.

 

Option D: Mesothelioma: This is a correct option. Asbestos exposure is a well-established risk factor for the development of mesothelioma, a malignant tumor of the mesothelial cells lining the pleura, peritoneum, and other serosal surfaces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diffuse alveolar damage is not typically associated with asbestosis but is more indicative of acute conditions such as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), distinguishing it from the chronic fibrotic changes seen in asbestosis.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 672)

questions.text: All are complication of typhoid ulcers except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stricture formation

 

Option B:

 

Stricture formation is not usually seen with enteric fever. It is a feature with intestinal tuberculosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Perforation: Perforation is a well-known complication of typhoid ulcers. The ulcers can penetrate through the intestinal wall, leading to perforation and potentially causing peritonitis.

 

Option C. Hemorrhage: Typhoid ulcers can cause bleeding, and hemorrhage is a recognized complication. Ulceration and erosion of blood vessels within the intestinal wall can result in gastrointestinal bleeding.

 

Option D. Sepsis: Perforation of typhoid ulcers can allow the entry of bacteria into the abdominal cavity, leading to sepsis. Sepsis is a severe, life-threatening complication that can result from the spread of bacteria and their toxins.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 791

questions.text: Which of the following is the commonest histological finding in benign hypertension?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyaline arteriolosclerosis

 

Option C:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Proliferative endarteritis is not the most common finding in benign hypertension. It involves inflammation and hyperplasia of the intima (inner layer) of arteries, often seen in conditions like vasculitis.

 

Option B. Necrotizing arteriolitis involves necrosis of the arterioles, and while it can occur in severe forms of hypertension, it is not the most common histological finding in benign hypertension.

 

Option D. Cystic medial necrosis is associated with conditions like Marfan syndrome and is characterized by degeneration and cystic changes in the arterial media. It is not a common finding in benign hypertension.

 

Educational objective:

 

The commonest histological finding in benign hypertension is Hyaline arteriolosclerosis.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ p492)

questions.text: A myocardial infarct showing early granulation tissue has most likely occurred:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Within 1 week

Option C:

Granulation tissue is a part of the healing process after a myocardial infarction (heart attack). It is typically seen within the first week following the infarct. During this phase of healing, inflammatory cells are replaced by granulation tissue, which consists of new blood vessels, fibroblasts, and other connective tissue elements.

Early granulation tissue, which consists of proliferating fibroblasts, new blood vessels (angiogenesis), and the resolution of the acute inflammatory infiltrate, typically appears between 4 and 7 days after an MI as part of the healing process.

Explanation:

Option A: Early granulation tissue does not develop less than 1 hour after an MI. The initial response is one of acute inflammation predominantly involving neutrophils.

Option B: Within 24 hours after an MI, coagulative necrosis begins to occur along with an acute inflammatory response, but granulation tissue is not yet present.

Option D: Within 1 month after an MI, the granulation tissue has usually matured into scar tissue, with dense collagen deposition, rather than early granulation tissue.

Educational Objective:

Early granulation tissue in the context of myocardial infarction typically occurs within 1 week after the event and signifies the replacement of inflammatory cells with new connective tissue elements and blood vessels.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 548)

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman complains of increased fatigue since last 2 years. Her serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen are raised. USG shows both kidneys symmetrically reduced in size. Kidney biopsy done shows the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Systemic hypertension

 

This is hyaline arteriosclerosis of vessel wall seen in benign hypertension wherein the kidneys are symmetrically contracted.

 

Similar changes can also be seen in diabetes mellitus.

 

Option B:

 

In systemic hypertension, especially long-standing and poorly controlled cases, hyaline arteriosclerosis of the vessel wall can occur, leading to symmetrically reduced kidney size. This finding is consistent with the patient’s presentation and biopsy results.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Polyarteritis nodosa typically presents with vasculitis and fibrinoid necrosis on kidney biopsy. It is characterized by segmental necrotizing inflammation of medium-sized arteries, which would be evident on histological examination.

 

Option C: Malignant hypertension typically presents with "flea-bitten" kidneys on imaging and demonstrates fibrinoid necrosis on kidney biopsy. This patient's presentation, including symmetrically reduced kidney size and the absence of fibrinoid necrosis, is not consistent with malignant hypertension.

 

Option D: Wegener's granulomatosis is characterized by granulomatous inflammation of the vessel wall. However, the histological findings described in the patient's kidney biopsy do not align with this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Symmetrically reduced kidney size with hyaline arteriosclerosis of the vessel wall is indicative of systemic hypertension.

 

Onion-skinning of blood vessels in kidney is seen in:

 

  • Malignant hypertension
  • Chronic transplant rejection
  • Thrombotic microangiopathies (e.g., HUS, TTP)

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ p492)

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presents with angina on exertion. His cardiovascular risk profile includes hypercholesterolemia and smoking. On histological examination of an arterial biopsy from an atherosclerotic plaque, numerous foam cells are identified. Which of the following components in the patient's blood most likely contributed to the formation of these foam cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oxidised LDL

The process described involves the formation of foam cells in atherosclerotic plaque. Foam cells are derived from macrophages that have engulfed modified low-density lipoproteins (LDL). In the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis, LDL cholesterol undergoes oxidative modifications, turning it into oxidized LDL. Oxidized LDL is more likely to be taken up by macrophages, leading to the formation of foam cells within the atherosclerotic plaque. The accumulation of foam cells contributes to the development and progression of atherosclerosis.

Option C:

oxidized LDL is readily taken up by macrophages through scavenger receptors, leading to foam cell formation, which is a hallmark of atherosclerotic plaque development.

Explanation:

Option A: Lipoproteins are the major carriers of cholesterol in the blood, but not all lipoproteins directly contribute to foam cell formation.

Option B: VLDL is a lipoprotein that primarily carries triglycerides; while it can contribute to plaque formation, it is not the most direct cause of foam cell formation.

Option D: Homocysteine is an amino acid that has been linked to an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, but it does not directly lead to foam cell formation.

Educational Objective:

Oxidized LDL is crucial in the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis as it is readily engulfed by macrophages to become foam cells, which are a defining feature of atherosclerotic plaques.

 

Robbins 10th 493-5

questions.text: In the evaluation of a patient with systemic vasculitis, which of the following conditions is least likely to show granulomatous inflammation on biopsy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Microscopic polyangiitis

 

Option D: 

 

  • Microscopic polyangiitis does not involve granulomatous inflammation; rather, it is associated with necrotizing inflammation that affects small vessels.

  • It is MPO-ANCA positive vasculitis disorder, characterized by pauci-immune glomerulonephritis and pulmonary capillaritis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Wegener's granulomatosis, now referred to as Granulomatosis with polyangiitis is known for necrotizing granulomatous inflammation, particularly affecting the respiratory tract and the kidneys.

 

c-ANCA positive (PR3-ANCA)

 

Option B: Buerger’s disease is characterized by granulomatous inflammation of small- and medium-sized arteries and veins in the extremities, especially in smokers

 

Associated with segmental thrombosing vasculitis with microabscesses and granulomatous inflammation.

 

Option C: Takayasu’s arteritis exhibits granulomatous inflammation of large vessels, particularly the aorta and its major branches.

 

Granulomatous thickening of the vessel wall, often leading to "pulseless disease"

 

Educational Objective:

 

MPA is a type of small-vessel vasculitis associated with necrotizing inflammation without granuloma formation, distinguishing it from the other options that are characterized by granulomatous inflammation.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 513)

choices.text: Crohn’s disease
Ulcerative colitis

questions.text: Granulomatous inflammation is found in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Crohn’s disease

Option A:

Characterized by granulomatous inflammation, which is one of the key histopathological features that can involve any segment of the GI tract. It is known for transmural inflammation, skip lesions, and granuloma formation.

Explanation:

Option B. Ulcerative colitis is a chronic inflammatory condition that affects the colonic mucosa with continuous lesions, but without the granulomas typical of Crohn's disease.

Option C. Amoebiasis, caused by Entamoeba histolytica, can result in ulcerative lesions within the GI tract but does not produce granulomatous inflammation.

Option D. Giardiasis, caused by the protozoan Giardia lamblia, typically results in malabsorption and diarrhea after affecting the small intestine, but without granulomas.

Educational Objective:

Granulomatous inflammation is a specific histopathological finding that supports the diagnosis of Crohn's disease and is not typically found in ulcerative colitis, amoebiasis, or giardiasis.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 801

choices.text: Majority of patients have associated atopic conditions
Feline esophagus is an endoscopic finding
Treatment of choice is high dose proton pump inhibitors
May be associated with food products like cow's milk and soy products

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Treatment of choice is high dose proton pump inhibitors

 

Option C:

 

The mainstay of treatment for EoE involves dietary modifications to eliminate food allergens and the use of topical steroids to reduce eosinophilic inflammation, not high-dose PPIs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Patients with EoE frequently have concurrent atopic conditions, which is a helpful clue in the diagnosis of this condition.

 

Option B. Feline esophagus is a term used to describe the ringed appearance of the esophagus seen during endoscopy in patients with EoE.

 

Option D. Food allergens such as cow's milk and soy are often implicated in EoE, and dietary elimination of these can be part of the management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The incorrect statement is (c). The treatment of choice for eosinophilic esophagitis is not high-dose proton pump inhibitors but rather dietary modifications and steroids.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 760

questions.text: Most common primary tumor of heart is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myxoma

 

Option A:

 

The most common primary tumor of the heart is a myxoma. Myxomas are typically benign tumors that most commonly arise in the atria of the heart. They are often found in the left atrium and can cause symptoms such as obstruction of blood flow, leading to issues like syncope and heart failure. Myxomas are composed of stellate or plump cells within a myxoid stroma.

 

Myxoma is indeed the most common primary tumor of the heart. These benign tumors are often found in the left atrium and can cause obstructive symptoms affecting blood flow.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a type of malignant soft tissue tumor that can occur in the heart, but it is not the most common primary cardiac tumor.

 

Option C: Fibroma is another type of benign cardiac tumor that typically occurs in children. While it can be found in the heart, it is not as common as myxoma.

 

Option D: Leiomyosarcoma is a malignant tumor of smooth muscle cells. It is rare in the heart and is not the most common primary cardiac tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common primary tumor of the heart is a myxoma, which is a benign growth that most commonly arises in the atria, particularly the left atrium, and can lead to symptoms related to blood flow obstruction.

 

 (Ref: Robbins 10th/579)

questions.text: Aschoff bodies in rheumatic heart disease show all of the following features, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epithelioid cell

 

Option B:

 

Aschoff bodies consist of foci of swollen eosinophilic collagen surrounded by lymphocytes (primarily T cells), occasional plasma cells, and plump macrophages called Anitschkow cells (pathognomonic for rheumatic fever). These cells are also called “caterpillar cells”. Some of the larger macrophages become multinucleated to form Aschoff giant cells.

 

Epithelioid cells are characteristic of granulomatous inflammation, such as seen in tuberculosis or sarcoidosis, not in rheumatic fever.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Anitschkow cells are a hallmark of Aschoff bodies found in rheumatic heart disease. They are plump macrophages with a central round nucleus, giving a caterpillar-like appearance.

 

Option C: Giant cells, or Aschoff giant cells, result from the fusion of macrophages and are a feature of Aschoff bodies.

 

Option D: Fibrinoid necrosis is typically associated with several vasculitis as well as Rheumatic heart disease

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aschoff bodies, pathognomonic for rheumatic fever, consist of swollen eosinophilic collagen, T cells, occasional plasma cells, Anitschkow cells, and Aschoff giant cells. Epithelioid cells are not a feature of Aschoff bodies and are instead associated with granulomatous inflammation.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 561)

questions.text: Neutrophilic infiltration with fibrinoid necrosis in walls of vessels is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Polyarteritis nodosa

Option D:

Neutrophilic infiltration with fibrinoid necrosis in the walls of vessels is a characteristic histopathological finding in Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). PAN is a systemic necrotizing vasculitis that primarily affects medium-sized arteries. The inflammatory process in PAN involves neutrophils infiltrating the vessel walls, leading to necrosis and damage to the affected arteries.

Explanation:

Option A: Giant cell arteritis is characterized by granulomatous inflammation rather than fibrinoid necrosis. It typically involves large to medium-sized arteries.

Option B: Takayasu arteritis involves large vessels, often the aorta and its main branches. Fibrinoid necrosis is not a prominent feature in Takayasu arteritis.

Option C: Churg-Strauss syndrome also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA), is characterized by eosinophilic infiltration and granulomatous inflammation. Fibrinoid necrosis is not a primary histopathological feature.

Educational objective:

 

Neutrophilic infiltration with fibrinoid necrosis in walls of vessels is seen in Polyarteritis Nodosa.

 

(Robbins 10th/ 512)

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a chronic cough and dyspnea. The sputum analysis reveals the presence of Charcot-Leyden crystals and Curschmann's spirals. Which of the following respiratory conditions is most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bronchial asthma

 

Option A:

 

Bronchial asthma have the sputum findings like Charcot-Leyden crystals (needle-shaped crystals composed of eosinophilic membrane protein) and Curschmann's spirals (spiral-shaped mucus plugs formed by the shedding of the bronchial mucosa).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Chronic bronchitis is characterized by inflammation of the bronchi, leading to increased mucus production and a persistent cough.

 

Option C: Bronchiectasis: In bronchiectasis, there is irreversible dilation of the bronchi.

 

Option D: Emphysema is characterized by the destruction of alveolar walls and airspace enlargement.

 

However, Charcot-Leyden crystals and Curschmann's spirals are not typically associated with chronic bronchitis, bronchiectasis and emphysema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Charcot-Leyden crystals and Curschmann's spirals in sputum is characteristic of bronchial asthma, reflecting eosinophilic inflammation and shedding of the bronchial mucosa, respectively, and are not typically found in chronic bronchitis, bronchiectasis, or emphysema.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 685)
